awd_titl_txt: The Role of Peroxy Radicals: Linking Gas-Phase Oxidation Chemistry to Secondary Organic Aerosol Formation
awd_abstract_narration:
This work focuses on improving the fundamental understanding of processes that contribute to the formation of secondary organic aerosol (SOA - very small particles formed from gas-phase compounds) in the atmosphere. A series of laboratory chamber experiments is being conducted to evaluate the atmospheric conditions and concentrations of various chemical species that lead to SOA formation.  The results of this research will lead to improved models for predicting SOA formation.

The objectives of this research are: (1) To experimentally map out the effects of the different reaction channels of peroxy radicals on SOA yields, gas- and aerosol-phase composition from photochemical oxidations of biogenic and anthropogenic hydrocarbons, and (2) To determine the effects of different peroxy radical reaction pathways on aerosol volatility. The proposed work focuses on oxidation by OH radicals under dry conditions (relative humidity < 1%).  Ammonium sulfate is being used as seeds for aerosol growth and hydrogen peroxide (H2O2), nitrous acid (HONO), or methyl nitrite (CH3ONO) is being used as the OH source. This research will also help improve understanding of how nitrogen oxides influence the SOA formation process.

The project includes outreach plans at the Columbia Middle School (a Title 1 school) to work with an Earth Science teacher and middle school students to increase their knowledge and experience in science, technology, engineering, and math (STEM) disciplines.

por.por_cntn:
In this project, we developed a new chemical ionization mass spectrometry (CIMS) technique to measure hydroperoxy radicals (HO2) directly using bromide (Br-) reagent ion. We conducted ambient measurements in Atlanta to demonstrate the capability of this direct measurement technique. Observations displayed expected diurnal profiles with the highest HO2 concentration observed in the afternoon. Measurement sensitivities of approximately 5.1±1.0 Hz/ppt for a bromide ion (79Br-) count rate of 106 counts per second were observed. The relatively low instrument background allowed for 3s lower detection limits of 0.7 ppt for 1 minute integration times. This sensitivity means that the instrument can be used for measuring atmospherically relevant HO2 levels. 

The formation of aerosols in laboratory chamber reactions are affected by peroxy radical fates as well as the loss of particles and vapors to chamber walls. We conducted a series of laboratory chamber experiments to investigate the influences of such loss processes on aerosol formation. We investigated the effect of seed aerosol surface area and oxidation rate on aerosol formation from α-pinene ozonolysis. We found that aerosol yields are independent of seed surface area. These results show that the extent to which vapor wall loss affects aerosol yields depends on the particular system and can be mitigated with excess oxidant concentrations. We also systematically assessed the uncertainties in the calculated aerosol mass concentrations between different particle-wall loss correction methods. Our study highlights the importance of accounting for particle-wall deposition accurately during laboratory chamber experiments.

In conducting photochemical oxidation experiments of isoprene, we found that organosulfates can be an important aerosol component.  We investigated the fragmentation patterns of organosulfur compounds and inorganic sulfate compounds in the aerosol mass spectrometer (AMS), an instrument commonly used to characterize aerosol composition. Based on the differences in their sulfate mass spectra, we developed a method to deconvolve total sulfate into components of inorganic and organic origins and applied this method in both laboratory and field measurements. For our isoprene photooxidation experiments, the apportionment results showed that organosulfur compounds can contribute ~10% of organic mass at peak aerosol growth. Our apportionment results demonstrate that organosulfur compounds could be a non-negligible source of sulfate fragments in laboratory experiments and ambient measurements.

The research supported by this project contributes to the training of graduate students from the School of Chemical and Biomolecular Engineering, as well as School of Earth and Atmospheric Sciences. The Br-CIMS provides a new measurement technique for important atmospheric radicals to understand their roles in gas oxidation and aerosol formation in the atmosphere.
